title: 111_hr3586
content: The Act may be cited as the "S Corporation ESOP Promotion and Expansion Act of 2009". Since 1998, employees have been allowed to own subchapter S corporations through ESOPs. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 incentivized businesses to become ESOP-owned S corporations, leading to thousands of companies and millions of Americans having ownership interests across various industries. Employees of ESOP-owned S corporations have valuable retirement savings accounts, providing job stability and meaningful retirement savings. Congress aims to support employee ownership of S corporations through ESOPs. SEC. 3 amends the definition of qualified securities for employee stock ownership plans sponsored by S corporations. SEC. 4 introduces a deduction for interest on loans to finance the purchase of employer securities by ESOPs sponsored by S corporations. SEC. 200 introduces interest deductions on loans for ESOPs sponsored by S corporations for purchasing employer securities. The deduction allows 50 percent of interest received by a bank on a securities acquisition loan for an ESOP sponsored by an S corporation to acquire employer securities. The deduction allows 50 percent of interest received by a bank on a securities acquisition loan for an ESOP sponsored by an S corporation to acquire employer securities. The terms of the loan to the employee stock ownership plan must be substantially similar to the terms of the loan to the S corporation. Refinancing loans are included in the definition of securities acquisition loans. The ESOP must hold more than 50 percent of stock after acquisition or transfer. The ESOP must own over 50% of S corporation stock after acquisition to qualify as a securities acquisition loan. Failure to maintain this minimum stock interest disqualifies the interest received from the deduction. The Secretary may exempt a plan from certain requirements if stock is acquired within a specified timeframe. Various interests may be treated as stock for compliance purposes in an Employee Stock Ownership Plan. The term 'employee stock ownership plan' is defined in section 4975(e)(7). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. SEC. 200 amends interest on loans for purchasing employer securities by an employee stock ownership plan. The effective date applies to loans made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5 addresses assumption of estate tax liability for transfers of employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S corporation. If employer securities are transferred to an employee stock ownership plan by gift or through the decedent's will, the executor can elect to apply a section relieving them of tax liability. This provision must be filed before the tax return due date. An employee stock ownership plan is required to pay a portion of the tax imposed by section 2001 if employer securities are transferred to the plan by gift, through the decedent's will, or by the executor of the estate. The executor of the estate shall pay a portion of the tax imposed by section 2001 with respect to the taxable estate of the decedent, which is determined by the value of employer securities in the gross estate or the tax imposed reduced by allowable credits. Installment payments can be elected by the executor. The executor may elect to have section 6166 apply to payment of estate tax on employer securities, allowing for installment payments before the tax return due date. Interest on installments for estate tax on employer securities is determined by aggregating the tax portions for the estate and employee stock ownership plan. Special rules apply for transfers of employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan, including no acceleration trigger and separate application of rules for estate and plan interests. Section 6166(g) applies separately to interests held by the estate and employee stock ownership plan after a transfer. Distributions or sales of securities by the plan are not considered dispositions for tax purposes, and such securities are not factored into subsequent dispositions. Dispositions of securities to meet diversification requirements are also addressed. Requirements for disposition of securities under section 401(a)(28) do not count as dispositions or withdrawals under section 6166(g). Employers with employees in an employee stock ownership plan must guarantee payments required by the plan. Agreements described in subsection (e) must be in effect for this guarantee. Agreements under subsection (e) require written consent from the plan administrator and employer for the application of subsections (b) and (d). An employee stock ownership plan assuming liability for tax under section 2001 is treated as a loan under section 4975(d)(3). Definitions for employer securities and employee stock ownership plan are provided in subsection (g). The terms 'employee stock ownership plan' and 'plan administrator' are defined in sections 4975(e)(7) and 414(g) respectively. The definition of 'tax imposed by section 2001' includes interest, penalties, and additional amounts related to the tax. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the Code. SEC. 2209A introduces liability for estate tax payments in cases of transferring employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S corporation. The effective date for these amendments applies to transfers made after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, SEC. 2057A allows for estate tax deductions for certain sales of employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S corporation. The estate tax law allows for a deduction when selling qualified employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S corporation. The deduction is equal to 50% of the proceeds from the sale. Qualified employer securities are those included in the decedent's gross estate. The estate tax law allows for a deduction when selling qualified employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S corporation. The deduction is equal to 50% of the proceeds from the sale. Qualified employer securities are those included in the decedent's gross estate. The term 'employer securities' is defined as per section 409(1) for the purposes of this section. The term 'employee stock ownership plan' is defined as a plan described in section 4975(e)(7) of the Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part IV of subchapter A of chapter 11 by inserting a new item after section 2057. Sales of employer securities to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S corporation. Effective Date: Amendments apply to sales of employer securities after the enactment of this Act. Department of Labor Technical Assistance Office. The Secretary of Labor must establish the S Corporation Employee Ownership Assistance Office within 90 days to promote employee ownership of S corporations. The office will provide education, outreach, and technical assistance for S corporations to implement employee stock ownership plans.
